titleStmt.title: Aratea Digital
Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, MS lat. 7299A

editionStmt.edition: Digital edition according to TEI P5

availability.licence: This document is published under the Creative Commons licence Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY 4.0).

msDesc.head: Collection with computistical, astronomical and astrological texts Limoges area, Saint-Martial de Limoges s. XI-XII Digital facsimile at gallica.bnf.fr Excerptum de astrologia De signis coeli Hyginus, De astronomia

supportDesc.collation: According to Juste the second codicological part consists of quaterniones: ff. 56-63, 64-71, 72-79, 80-87 and 88-95.
supportDesc.condition: Missing one quire between ff. 63 and 64.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Written in Carolinginan minuscle. The second part is written by a single hand.

history.origin: The manuscript consists of two contemporary codicological units. There are several suggestions about the place and date of production: Limoges area (Folkerts) more specifically Abbey of Solignac (Borst) or Saint-Martial de Limoges (Juste) in s. XI (Gautier-Dalché, Munk Olsen), before 1050 (Borst) or s. XII (Van de Vyver, Burnett). Meyer Schapiro suggested 1097, based on a mark made in the calendar in the first codicological part(see a note in the BNF).

listBibl.head: Selected Bibliography:
listBibl.bibl: Juste, David. Les Alchandreana primitifs: Étude sur les plus anciens traités astrologiques latin d’origin arabe (Xe siècle). Leiden: Brill, 2007, pp. 352-355.
Borst, Arno. Das Buch der Naturgeschichte: Plinius und seine Leser im Zeitalter des Pergaments. Heidelberg: Winter, 1994.
Burnett, Charles. ‘Adelard, Ergaphalau and the Science of the Stars’. In Burnett, Magic and Divination in the Middle Ages, 133–45, 1996, esp. p. 141.
Burnett, Charles. ‘L’astronomie à Chartres au temps de l’évêque Fulbert’. In Le temps de Fulbert. Enseigner le Moyen Âge à partir d’un monument, 91–103, 1996, esp. p. 101.

Folkerts, Menso. ‘De Artithmetics Propositionibus. A Mathematical Treatise Ascribed to the Venerable Bede’. In Essays on Early Medieval Mathematics: The Latin Tradition, (III) 1-30. Aldershot: Variorum, esp. pp. 5-6.
Gautier-Dalché, Patrick. ‘Mappae mundi antérieures au XIIIe s. dans les manuscrits latins de la bibliothèque nationale de France’. Scriptorium 52 (1998): 102–62.
Munk Olsen, Birger. ‘Chronique des manuscrits classiques latins (IXe-XIIe siècles), IV’. Revue d’histoire des textes 30 (2000): 123–88, p. 166.
Van de Vyver, A. ‘Les plus anciennes traductions latines médiévales (Xe-XIe siècles) de traités d’astronomie et d’astrologie’. Osiris 1 (1936): 658–91, esp. pp. 666, 679 (cited as latin 7292 A).

msItem.title: Alchandreana (Proportiones 11-35)
msItem.incipit: Paupertate unius cuiusque XI. Quicumque uero desiderat nosse aut paupertatem aut copiam cuiusque inspiciat planetam
msItem.explicit: IIII inutilis et natus in ea decorus erit, V inutilis.
msItem.note: The manuscript lost probably one quire, since the text ends abbruptly and the next one is acephalous.

msItem.author: Hyginus
msItem.title: De astronomia (excerpts from Book 2, 3 and 4 on the zodiacal signs)
msItem.incipit: omnino XVI. Corona autem centauri est stellarum VII. De decimo signo capricorni. Capricornus huius effigies similis est egippam
msItem.note: The excerpts start only with the end of the ninth to the twelfth sign - Sagittarius, Capricornus, Aquarius and Pisces. For each of the twelve zodiacal signs there are the respective excerpts from Book 2 on their mythological origin (often shortened), from Book 3 on their position within the celestial circles, and (for some) from Book 4 the paranatellonta and the number of stars in each constellation.

msItem.title: De sideribus
msItem.incipit: Ad boreae partem arctae uertuntur anguis
msItem.explicit: Hinc sequitur pistrix simul erida inique fluenta.

msItem.title: Excerptum de astrologia
msItem.incipit: Duo sunt extremi uerticem mundi quos appellant polon

msItem.author: Isidore
msItem.title: De natura rerum (excerpt from cap. 26 De nominibus stellarum)
msItem.incipit: Legitur in libro iob dicentem domino numquid coniungere uales
msItem.explicit: hic autem in celi axe constitutu semper uersatur ut numquam mergitur. Arcton igitur.

msItem.author: Bede
msItem.title: De natura rerum (cap. 1-24)
msItem.incipit: Naturas rerum uarias labentis et aeui capitula

msItem.note: Short text of 4 lines on astrology: repente nascentes regni commutationem aut pestilenciam aut bella uel uentose sti usuae portendentes quarum alie mouentur errancium modo alie immobiles erent omnes sub ipsos septemtrionem aut aliqua eius parte non terra.

msItem.author: Isidore
msItem.title: Etymologiae (cap. 24-71)
msItem.incipit: De magnitudine lune (Capitula 48-71) Astronomia est astrorum lex

msItem.title: De signis coeli
msItem.incipit: Helix arcturus maior habet autem in capite stellas obscuras VII
msItem.explicit: CCCXL octo diebus signiferum cursum suum complens.
msItem.note: The text has all chapters. It shares most of the smaller omissions and readings found only in Amiens, BM MS 222 (e.g. cap. XXII, 5 Gorgonis autem, cap. XXXIX, 1 in cuius medio urna esse dicitur et super cuius caudam coruum sedentem in Amiens 222; in cuius medio urnam esse dicunt here). Amiens 222 is missing cap. I-XVI and XLI. Amiens 222 includes further smaller omissions (e.g. cap. XX, 2 angulos; cap. XXX, 4 genu I, present in Paris 7299A), so that it is not possible that it served as the exemplar of the Paris MS, but they could have been copied from one exemplar. Our MS has the last chapter XLI transmitted, according to Dell'Era only in three other MSS: Durham, The Dean and Chapter Library Hunter Ms. 100, Montecassino, Archivo della Badia 3 and Wolfenbüttel, Herzog August Bibliothek, Gud. lat. 132. Shares the omission in cap. IV, 3 like the Wolfenbüttel MS, Paris lat. 5239, and BAV Reg. lat. 598.

msItem.author: Sisebut
msItem.title: Carmen de eclipsibus
msItem.incipit: Tu forte in lucu lentus uaga carmina gignis
msItem.explicit: Luna meat fratrem rectis obiectibus argens.

msItem.incipit: Imago dei est secundum augustinum genelaliter in omnibus quae a deo facte sunt
msItem.explicit: simile sit et nullo modo diuersum alter in diuersitatibus appareat.

msItem.title: Alchandreana (Proportiones 1-10)
msItem.rubric: Incipiunt proportiones competentes in astrorum industris
msItem.incipit: De exordio omnes creaturae herus humanicus
msItem.explicit: pauperioris in reditu. De copia aut.
msItem.note: Interlinear notes from a 14th- or 15th-c hand.

msItem.title: Annalis libellus (with omissions)
msItem.incipit: Quod modis solet annus nominari. Primus modus est de luna

msItem.title: Alchandreana (Quicumque 9,2-5)
msItem.incipit: Draco semper abire dicitur retrorsum incipiens a leone decurrit in cancrum
msItem.explicit: in quo predicti draconis fuerit caput.
msItem.note: Copied as part of the computistical collection.
